Standard models of degree 111 del Pezzo fibrations

Konstantin Loginov
Abstract.

We construct a standard birational model (a model that has Gorenstein canonical singularities) for the three-dimensional del Pezzo fibrations π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶{\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C} of degree 111 and relative Picard number 111. We also embed the standard model into the relative weighted projective space ℙC​(1,1,2,3)subscriptℙ𝐶1123\mathbb{P}_{C}(1,1,2,3). Our construction works in the G𝐺G-equivariant category where G𝐺G is a finite group.

Partially supported by the Russian Academic Excellence Project ’5-100’, the Simons Foundation and the grants RFBR-15-01-02164 and MK-6019.2016.1.

Introduction

The Minimal Model Program (the MMP for short, see [Ma02], [KMM87]) is a powerful tool that helps to understand the birational properties of algebraic varieties. The minimal category in which it works is the category 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} of the projective varieties with at worst terminal ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-factorial singularities. The result of applying this program to a projective variety is either a minimal model, that is a variety X∈𝒞𝑋𝒞X\in\mathcal{C} whose canonical divisor class KXsubscript𝐾𝑋K_{X} is nef, or a Fano–Mori fibration, that is a variety X∈𝒞𝑋𝒞X\in\mathcal{C} admitting a contraction morphism π:X⟶B:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐵\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B whose fibers are of positive dimension, the anti-canonical divisor class −KXsubscript𝐾𝑋-K_{X} is relatively ample, and ρ​(X/B)=1𝜌𝑋𝐵1\rho(X/B)=1.

We will focus on the three-dimensional case. In this case, the base B𝐵B of the Fano–Mori fibration π:X⟶B:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐵\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B can be of dimension 00, 111 or 222. If dimB=0dimension𝐵0\dim B=0 then X𝑋X is a (possibly singular) Fano variety. It is known that Fano varieties lie in a finite number of algebraic families. However, they are classified only in the smooth case. In the singular case there are partial classificational results (see e.g. [Pr16a]).

If dimB=2dimension𝐵2\dim B=2 then a general fiber of π𝜋\pi is a non-singular rational curve. In this case, π:X⟶B:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐵\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B is called a ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-conic fibration. It is known that in this case there exists a standard model, that is a ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-conic fibration π′:X′⟶B′:superscript𝜋′⟶superscript𝑋′superscript𝐵′\pi^{\prime}\colon X^{\prime}\longrightarrow B^{\prime} where X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime} and B′superscript𝐵′B^{\prime} are non-singular, X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime} is fiberwise birationally equivalent to X𝑋X, and ρ​(X′/B′)=1𝜌superscript𝑋′superscript𝐵′1\rho(X^{\prime}/B^{\prime})=1 (see [Sa82]).

Finally, if dimB=1dimension𝐵1\dim B=1 then a general fiber of π𝜋\pi is a non-singular del Pezzo surface. In this situation the fibration π:X⟶B:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐵\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B is called a ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration. Standard models of such fibrations were considered in the work of A. Corti [Co96], see also [Ko97].

For the applications to the problem of classification of the finite subgroups in the Cremona group (see e. g. [PrSh16]), as well as for birational classification of varieties over algebraically non-closed fields one should change the category 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. We will work with the varieties defined over an arbitrary field of characteristic 00 that admit an action of a finite group G𝐺G. In this case, we can apply the G𝐺G-equivariant Minimal Model Program (the G𝐺G-MMP, see [KM98, 2.18, 2.19], [Mo88, 0.3.14]). Again, a final product of applying this program can be either a G𝐺G-minimal model, or a G𝐺G-Fano–Mori fibration. For a three-dimensional G𝐺G-Fano–Mori fibration π:X⟶B:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐵\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B, as in the “classical” situation, we have three possibilities:

  • •

    G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-Fano varieties. In general, this class is poorly understood. Partial results can be found in the works [Pr15], [Pr16], [Pr16a], [PrSh16].

  • •

    G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-conic fibrations. In this case existence of the standard model is proven in the work [Av14].

  • •

    G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibrations (see Definition 1.5). In the present work, we construct standard models of G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibrations of degree 111.

The following theorems are the main results of this paper (the necessary definitions are given in §1).

Theorem A.

Let X𝑋X be a projective three-dimensional G𝐺G-variety and C𝐶C be a G𝐺G-curve. Let π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C be a proper G𝐺G-morphism whose generic fiber is a non-singular degree 111 del Pezzo surface Xηsubscript𝑋𝜂X_{\eta}, and PicG​(X/C)superscriptPic𝐺𝑋𝐶\mathrm{Pic}^{G}(X/C) is generated by −KXsubscript𝐾𝑋-K_{X} and G𝐺G-components of fibers of π𝜋\pi. Then there exists a Gorenstein model, that is a generalised G𝐺G-del Pezzo fibration σ:Y⟶C′:𝜎⟶𝑌superscript𝐶′\sigma\colon Y\longrightarrow C^{\prime} such that

  1. (i)

    the following diagram is commutative

    where χ𝜒\chi is a birational G𝐺G-equivariant map,

  2. (ii)

    Y𝑌Y has only ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-factorial canonical Gorenstein singularities,

  3. (iii)

    C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} is non-singular and projective,

  4. (iv)

    χ𝜒\chi induces an isomorphism between Xηsubscript𝑋𝜂X_{\eta} and Yη′subscript𝑌superscript𝜂′Y_{\eta^{\prime}} where Yη′subscript𝑌superscript𝜂′Y_{\eta^{\prime}} is the generic fiber of σ𝜎\sigma,

  5. (v)

    any fiber of σ𝜎\sigma is reduced and irreducible.

Corollary B.

If π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi:X\longrightarrow C is a G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration of degree 111 then it has a model with at worst ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-factorial canonical Gorenstein singularities, with irreducible fibers and with the same generic fiber as π𝜋\pi.

Theorem C.

Let σ:Y⟶C:𝜎⟶𝑌𝐶\sigma\colon Y\longrightarrow C be a generalised G𝐺G-del Pezzo fibration of degree 111, and let Y have only Gorenstein canonical singularities. Then Y𝑌Y admits an embedding over C𝐶C into the relative weighted projective space

Y↪ℙC​(1,1,2,3).↪𝑌subscriptℙ𝐶1123Y\hookrightarrow\mathbb{P}_{C}(1,1,2,3).

We prove these results in several steps. First, in §1, Proposition 1.7, we give the main definitions and prove some preliminary results. Second, in §2 we establish some rigidity properties for del Pezzo surfaces and del Pezzo fibrations of degree 111. Third, in §3, Proposition 3.1, starting from a del Pezzo fibration of degree 111 as in Theorem A, we show that X𝑋X is G𝐺G-birational over C𝐶C to a G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration of degree 111. After that, in 3.2 we construct a canonical model of X𝑋X, that is a fibration π¯:X¯⟶C:¯𝜋⟶¯𝑋𝐶\bar{\pi}\colon\bar{X}\longrightarrow C which is G𝐺G-birational to X𝑋X over C𝐶C and such that the pair (X¯,|−KX¯+π¯∗​D¯|)¯𝑋subscript𝐾¯𝑋superscript¯𝜋¯𝐷(\bar{X},|-K_{\bar{X}}+\bar{\pi}^{*}\bar{D}|) is canonical for some D¯¯𝐷\bar{D}. Next, in §4, Theorem 4.3, we construct a Gorenstein model which proves Theorem A. After that, in §​5§5\S\ref{section-5}, we recall some facts on the anticanonical algebra of degree 111 del Pezzo surfaces. Finally, in §6, we embed a Gorenstein G𝐺G-fibration Y𝑌Y into ℙC​(1,1,2,3)subscriptℙ𝐶1123\mathbb{P}_{C}(1,1,2,3) proving Theorem C.

The author is grateful to his scientific advisor Yu. Prokhorov for posing the problem and constant support in writing the paper, and to A. Kuznetsov and C. Shramov for many helpful discussions.

1. Preliminaries

We work over a field of characteristic 00, not necessarily algebraically closed. We also fix a finite group G𝐺G. Recall the standard definitions.

Definition 1.1.

An algebraic variety X𝑋X is called a G𝐺G-variety (or a variety with an action of the group G𝐺G) if there exists a homomorphism (not necessarily injective)

ϕ:G⟶Aut​X.:italic-ϕ⟶𝐺Aut𝑋{\phi:G\longrightarrow\mathrm{Aut}\ X}.
Definition 1.2.

A rational map of G𝐺G-varieties f:X⇢Y:𝑓⇢𝑋𝑌f:X\dashrightarrow Y is called a G𝐺G-map if f𝑓f commutes with the action of the group G𝐺G on X𝑋X and on Y𝑌Y. If the map f𝑓f is birational we say that X𝑋X is G𝐺G-birational to Y𝑌Y. If the map f𝑓f is a morphism then f𝑓f is called a G𝐺G-morphism.

Definition 1.3.

A G𝐺G-variety X𝑋X is called G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-factorial if any G𝐺G-invariant Weil divisor is ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-Cartier.

Let us fix the notation. For a vector space (or a vector bundle) A𝐴A we denote its k𝑘k-th symmetric power by Sk​Asuperscript𝑆𝑘𝐴S^{k}A, and its full symmetric power by S∙​Asuperscript𝑆∙𝐴S^{\bullet}A. The base locus of a linear system ℒℒ\mathscr{L} on X𝑋X we denote by Bs​ℒBsℒ\mathrm{Bs}\ \mathscr{L}. Let π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi:X\longrightarrow C be a proper morphism onto the variety C𝐶C. By η𝜂\eta we denote the generic point of C𝐶C, and by Xηsubscript𝑋𝜂X_{\eta} the generic fiber of π𝜋\pi. By a general fiber we mean a fiber over some closed point in an open subset U⊂C𝑈𝐶U\subset C. We denote by Z1​(X/C)subscript𝑍1𝑋𝐶Z_{1}(X/C) a free abelian group generated by reduced irreducible curves which are mapped to points by π𝜋\pi. There is a natural intersection pairing

(,):Pic(X)×Z1(X/C)⟶ℤ.(\ ,\ ):\mathrm{Pic}(X)\times Z_{1}(X/C)\longrightarrow\mathbb{Z}.

We put Pic(X/C)=Pic(X)/≡\mathrm{Pic}(X/C)=\mathrm{Pic}(X)/\equiv where ≡\equiv is the numerical equivalence with respect to the pairing introduced above. We denote by ρ​(X/C)𝜌𝑋𝐶\rho(X/C) the dimension of Pic​(X/C)Pic𝑋𝐶\mathrm{Pic}(X/C) and by ρG​(X/C)superscript𝜌𝐺𝑋𝐶\rho^{G}(X/C) the dimension of the G𝐺G-invariant subspace PicG​(X/C)superscriptPic𝐺𝑋𝐶\mathrm{Pic}^{G}(X/C).

Let D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} be divisors on X𝑋X. We write D∼𝐶D′𝐶similar-to𝐷superscript𝐷′D\mathrel{\underset{\scriptscriptstyle{C}}{\sim}}D^{\prime} if D∼D′+π∗​Esimilar-to𝐷superscript𝐷′superscript𝜋𝐸D\sim D^{\prime}+\pi^{*}E for some Cartier divisor E𝐸E on C𝐶C. If ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-divisors on X𝑋X are ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-linearly equivalent we write D∼ℚD′ℚsimilar-to𝐷superscript𝐷′D\mathrel{\underset{\scriptscriptstyle{\mathbb{Q}}}{\sim}}D^{\prime}. Finally, we write D∼ℚ,CD′ℚ𝐶similar-to𝐷superscript𝐷′D\mathrel{\underset{\scriptscriptstyle{\mathbb{Q},C}}{\sim}}D^{\prime} if ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-divisors D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} on X𝑋X are ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-linearly equivalent over C𝐶C, that is D∼ℚD′+π∗​Eℚsimilar-to𝐷superscript𝐷′superscript𝜋𝐸D\mathrel{\underset{\scriptscriptstyle{\mathbb{Q}}}{\sim}}D^{\prime}+\pi^{*}E.

We introduce the main definitions.

Definition 1.4.

A del Pezzo surface S𝑆S is a (not necessarily normal) projective surface that has at worst Gorenstein singularities and whose anti-canonical divisor class −KSsubscript𝐾𝑆-K_{S} is ample. The degree of a del Pezzo surface S𝑆S is the number (−KS)2superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑆2(-K_{S})^{2}.

Definition 1.5.

Let X𝑋X be a three-dimensional normal projective G𝐺G-variety with at worst terminal singularities and let C𝐶C be a non-singular G𝐺G-curve. Assume that

  1. (i)

    X𝑋X is G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-factorial;

  2. (ii)

    there exists a projective G𝐺G-morphism with connected fibers π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C;

  3. (iii)

    −KXsubscript𝐾𝑋-K_{X} is π𝜋\pi-ample;

  4. (iv)

    π𝜋\pi is an extremal contraction, that is ρG​(X/C)=1superscript𝜌𝐺𝑋𝐶1\rho^{G}(X/C)=1.

Then π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C is called a G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration. The degree of a G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration is the degree of its generic fiber Xηsubscript𝑋𝜂X_{\eta}. Since X𝑋X is terminal Xηsubscript𝑋𝜂X_{\eta} is a non-singular del Pezzo surface. If X𝑋X has Gorenstein singularities we call π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C a G𝐺G-del Pezzo fibration.

Definition 1.6.

We call π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C a generalised G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration if X𝑋X has at worst canonical singularities and the conditions (ii) and (iii) of the definition 1.5 are satisfied. Notice that in this case the generic fiber Xηsubscript𝑋𝜂X_{\eta} can be singular.

We will work with the anticanonical linear system on X𝑋X.

Proposition 1.7 ([Al94, 2.17, 2.19]).

Let π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C be a G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration. Then there exists a divisor D𝐷D (which we may assume to be G𝐺G-invariant) on C𝐶C such that the linear system ℋ=|−KX+π∗​D|ℋsubscript𝐾𝑋superscript𝜋𝐷\mathscr{H}=|-K_{X}+\pi^{*}D| on X𝑋X is non-empty and has no fixed components.

We will use the language of singularities of the linear systems, introduced in [Al94, 1.8] and [Co95]. It is easy to see that for a G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration the restriction of the linear system ℋℋ\mathscr{H} chosen above to a general fiber of the morphism π𝜋\pi is surjective. If the degree of a general fiber is 111 then the linear system ℋℋ\mathscr{H} has one simple base-point on it. Hence it is easy to see that the pair (X,ℋ)𝑋ℋ(X,\mathscr{H}) is canonical outside a finite number of fibers. Our aim is to construct a canonical model for the pair (X,ℋ)𝑋ℋ(X,\mathscr{H}). We will need the following lemmas:

Lemma 1.8.

Let π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C be a generalised Gorenstein G𝐺G-del Pezzo fibration (that is, KXsubscript𝐾𝑋K_{X} is Cartier) of degree d𝑑d with at worst canonical singularities. Let F𝐹F be the scheme fiber over a closed point. Write F=∑mi​Fi𝐹subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖F=\sum m_{i}F_{i} where Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} are irreducible components. Then ∑mi≤dsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑑\sum m_{i}\leq d. In particular, if d=1𝑑1d=1, then any geometric fiber is reduced and irreducible.

Proof.

We may assume the ground field to be algebraically closed. By the adjunction formula KX|F=KFevaluated-atsubscript𝐾𝑋𝐹subscript𝐾𝐹K_{X}|_{F}=K_{F}, and we have

d=(−KF)2=(−KX)2⋅F=(−KX)2⋅∑mi​Fi=∑mi​(−KF|Fi)2≥∑mi,𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐾𝐹2⋅superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑋2𝐹⋅superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑋2subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptevaluated-atsubscript𝐾𝐹subscript𝐹𝑖2subscript𝑚𝑖d=(-K_{F})^{2}=(-K_{X})^{2}\cdot F=(-K_{X})^{2}\cdot\sum m_{i}F_{i}=\sum m_{i}(-K_{F}|_{F_{i}})^{2}\geq\sum m_{i},

the last inequality holds since −KFsubscript𝐾𝐹-K_{F} is an ample Cartier divisor on Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}. ∎

Lemma 1.9 ([Al94, 1.22]).

Suppose that the pair (X,ℋ)𝑋ℋ(X,\mathscr{H}) is terminal where ℋℋ\mathscr{H} is a linear system without fixed components. Then ℋℋ\mathscr{H} has at worst isolated non-singular base-points Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} such that multPi​ℋ=1subscriptmultsubscript𝑃𝑖ℋ1\mathrm{mult}_{P_{i}}\mathscr{H}=1.

Lemma 1.10 ([Al94, 1.23]).

Suppose that X𝑋X has only terminal singularities and the pair (X,ℋ)𝑋ℋ(X,\mathscr{H}) is canonical. Then in the neighbourhood of any base-point P𝑃P of ℋℋ\mathscr{H} we have ℋ∼−KXsimilar-toℋsubscript𝐾𝑋\mathscr{H}\sim-K_{X}.

2. Birational rigidity

The following lemma is a variant of birational rigidity of degree 111 del Pezzo surfaces (cf. [Is96, 1.6]).

Lemma 2.1.

Let S𝑆S be a non-singular del Pezzo surface of degree 111, and let T𝑇T be either a normal del Pezzo surface of degree d𝑑d or a conic bundle over a non-singular curve. Let f:S⇢T:𝑓⇢𝑆𝑇f:S\dashrightarrow T be a birational map between them. Put

ℋ={|−KT|,if ​d≥3,|−2​KT|,if ​d=2,|−3​KT|,if ​d=1,|n​F|,where F is the class of a fiber if T is a conic bundle, n≥1.ℋcasessubscript𝐾𝑇if 𝑑3otherwise2subscript𝐾𝑇if 𝑑2otherwise3subscript𝐾𝑇if 𝑑1otherwise𝑛𝐹where F is the class of a fiber if T is a conic bundle, n≥1.otherwise\mathscr{H}=\begin{cases}|-K_{T}|,\ \text{if }d\geq 3,\\ |-2K_{T}|,\ \text{if }d=2,\\ |-3K_{T}|,\ \text{if }d=1,\\ |nF|,\text{where $F$ is the class of a fiber if T is a conic bundle, $n\geq 1$.}\end{cases}

Suppose that ℒ:=f∗−1​ℋ⊂|−a​KS|assignℒsubscriptsuperscript𝑓1ℋ𝑎subscript𝐾𝑆\mathscr{L}:=f^{-1}_{*}\mathscr{H}\subset|-aK_{S}| for some positive integer a𝑎a. Then T𝑇T is a degree 111 del Pezzo surface and f𝑓f is an isomorphism.

Proof.

All the properties in the claim can be checked over an algebraically closed field, so we assume that. Consider a resolution of the points of indeterminacy of f𝑓f

Consider the case where T𝑇T is a del Pezzo surface. Since in this case ℋℋ\mathscr{H} is very ample (see Proposition 5.1) hℎh is the blow up of the base locus of ℒℒ\mathscr{L}. It is easy to check (see [Is96, 1.3.2]) that for the strict transform ℒ~:=g∗−1​ℒassign~ℒsubscriptsuperscript𝑔1ℒ\widetilde{\mathscr{L}}:=g^{-1}_{*}\mathscr{L} we have

ℒ~2=ℒ2−∑ri2superscript~ℒ2superscriptℒ2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖2\widetilde{\mathscr{L}}^{2}=\mathscr{L}^{2}-\sum r_{i}^{2}
KZ⋅ℒ~=KS⋅ℒ+∑ri⋅subscript𝐾𝑍~ℒ⋅subscript𝐾𝑆ℒsubscript𝑟𝑖K_{Z}\cdot\widetilde{\mathscr{L}}=K_{S}\cdot\mathscr{L}+\sum r_{i}

where risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} are the multiplicities of the base points of ℒℒ\mathscr{L} (including infinitely near ones). Notice that ℒ~=h∗−1​ℋ~ℒsubscriptsuperscriptℎ1ℋ\widetilde{\mathscr{L}}=h^{-1}_{*}\mathscr{H}, and since ℋℋ\mathscr{H} is base point free we get

ℋ2=ℒ~2=ℒ2−∑ri2=a2−∑ri2superscriptℋ2superscript~ℒ2superscriptℒ2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖2superscript𝑎2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖2\mathscr{H}^{2}=\widetilde{\mathscr{L}}^{2}=\mathscr{L}^{2}-\sum r_{i}^{2}=a^{2}-\sum r_{i}^{2}
ℋ⋅KT=KZ⋅ℒ~=−a+∑ri⋅ℋsubscript𝐾𝑇⋅subscript𝐾𝑍~ℒ𝑎subscript𝑟𝑖\mathscr{H}\cdot K_{T}=K_{Z}\cdot\widetilde{\mathscr{L}}=-a+\sum r_{i}

Consider the cases:

1) d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3. We get

a2=∑ri2+d,a=∑ri+d.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑎2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖2𝑑𝑎subscript𝑟𝑖𝑑a^{2}=\sum r_{i}^{2}+d,\ \ \ a=\sum r_{i}+d.

It follows that ri=0subscript𝑟𝑖0r_{i}=0 for any i𝑖i and d=1𝑑1d=1 which contradicts the assumption.

2) d=2𝑑2d=2. We get

a2=∑ri2+8,a=∑ri+4.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑎2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖28𝑎subscript𝑟𝑖4a^{2}=\sum r_{i}^{2}+8,\ \ \ a=\sum r_{i}+4.

These equations easily lead to a contradiction.

3) d=1𝑑1d=1. Then we get the equations

a2=∑ri2+9,a=∑ri+3.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑎2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖29𝑎subscript𝑟𝑖3a^{2}=\sum r_{i}^{2}+9,\ \ \ a=\sum r_{i}+3.

We deduce that all the ri=0subscript𝑟𝑖0r_{i}=0, hence the map f𝑓f is a morphism and a=3𝑎3a=3. Thus f𝑓f is a contraction of the exception divisor E𝐸E. Hence

KS=f∗​KT+Esubscript𝐾𝑆superscript𝑓subscript𝐾𝑇𝐸K_{S}=f^{*}K_{T}+E

On the other hand, a​KS=f∗​KT𝑎subscript𝐾𝑆superscript𝑓subscript𝐾𝑇aK_{S}=f^{*}K_{T}. Hence (1−a)​KS=E1𝑎subscript𝐾𝑆𝐸(1-a)K_{S}=E which is absurd. We see that there are no contracted curves and f𝑓f is an isomorphism.

Now consider the case when T𝑇T is a conic bundle over a non-singular curve. That is there is a morphism τ:T⟶B:𝜏⟶𝑇𝐵\tau:T\longrightarrow B whose general fiber is a non-singular conic. We have ℋ2=(n​F)2=0superscriptℋ2superscript𝑛𝐹20\mathscr{H}^{2}=(nF)^{2}=0 and ℋ⋅KT=n​F⋅KT=−2​n⋅ℋsubscript𝐾𝑇⋅𝑛𝐹subscript𝐾𝑇2𝑛\mathscr{H}\cdot K_{T}=nF\cdot K_{T}=-2n by adjunction. Considering the resolution of the base points of ℒℒ\mathscr{L} we can write the formulas as above and get

a2=∑ri2,a=∑ri+2​n.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑎2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖2𝑎subscript𝑟𝑖2𝑛a^{2}=\sum r_{i}^{2},\ \ \ a=\sum r_{i}+2n.

Again, it is easy to derive a contradiction.

We see that only the case 3) can occur, and the claim follows. ∎

The next proposition gives a generalization of the rigidity property to degree 111 del Pezzo fibrations.

Proposition 2.2.

Let X𝑋X be a projective three-dimensional G𝐺G-variety and C𝐶C be a non-singular G𝐺G-curve. Let π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C be a G𝐺G-morphism whose generic fiber is a non-singular degree 111 del Pezzo surface Xηsubscript𝑋𝜂X_{\eta}, and PicG​(X/C)superscriptPic𝐺𝑋𝐶\mathrm{Pic}^{G}(X/C) is generated by −KXsubscript𝐾𝑋-K_{X} and G𝐺G-components of fibers. Then ψ𝜓\psi is an isomorphism, X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime} is a G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration of degree 111 and Xη≃Xη′similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑋𝜂subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝜂X_{\eta}\simeq X^{\prime}_{\eta}. Here Xη′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝜂X^{\prime}_{\eta} is the generic fiber of X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime} over C𝐶C.

Proof.

Then Xη′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝜂X^{\prime}_{\eta} is a del Pezzo surface over the function field of C𝐶C. We want to apply Lemma 2.1.

First consider the case when Xη′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝜂X^{\prime}_{\eta} is a degree 111 del Pezzo surface. By adjunction we have −3​KX′|Xη′=−3​KXη′evaluated-at3subscript𝐾superscript𝑋′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝜂3subscript𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝜂-3K_{X^{\prime}}|_{X^{\prime}_{\eta}}=-3K_{X^{\prime}_{\eta}}. If Xη′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝜂X^{\prime}_{\eta} is a del Pezzo surface of degree d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2 a similar argument yields a contradiction.

Now suppose that B𝐵B is a surface in which case Xη′subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝜂X^{\prime}_{\eta} as a surface over the function field of C𝐶C admits a conic bundle structure. 3. Canonical model

First we construct a model that is a G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration in the sense of Definition 1.5.

Proposition 3.1.

4. Gorenstein model

We need the following technical proposition that follows easily from Kodaira’s Lemma (see e. g. [KMM87, 0.3.5]).

Proposition 4.1.

Let B𝐵B be a nef big ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-Cartier divisor on a normal projective variety X𝑋X with at worst terminal singularities. Then there exists an ample ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-Cartier divisor A𝐴A and an effective ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-Cartier divisor N𝑁N such that B∼ℚA+Nℚsimilar-to𝐵𝐴𝑁B\mathrel{\underset{\scriptscriptstyle{\mathbb{Q}}}{\sim}}A+N and the pair (X,N)𝑋𝑁(X,N) is terminal.

We also use the construction of a terminal modification of a pair.

Proposition 4.2 ([Co95, 2.8]).

Let X𝑋X be a normal projective G𝐺G-variety with at worst terminal singularities and let the pair (X,ℋ)𝑋ℋ(X,\mathscr{H}) be canonical. Then there exists a G𝐺G-equivariant terminal modification, that is a G𝐺G-variety X¯¯𝑋\bar{X} and a birational G𝐺G-morphism f:X¯⟶X:𝑓⟶¯𝑋𝑋f\colon\bar{X}\longrightarrow X such that the pair (X¯,ℋ¯)¯𝑋¯ℋ(\bar{X},\bar{\mathscr{H}}) is terminal where ℋ¯=f∗−1​ℋ¯ℋsubscriptsuperscript𝑓1ℋ\bar{\mathscr{H}}=f^{-1}_{*}\mathscr{H} and the following formula holds

KX¯+ℋ¯=f∗​(KX+ℋ).subscript𝐾¯𝑋¯ℋsuperscript𝑓subscript𝐾𝑋ℋK_{\bar{X}}+\bar{\mathscr{H}}=f^{*}(K_{X}+\mathscr{H}).

Now we construct a Gorenstein model.

Theorem 4.3.

Let π:X⟶C:𝜋⟶𝑋𝐶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C be a G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration of degree 111. Then there exists a Gorenstein model, that is a generalised G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration σ:Y⟶C:𝜎⟶𝑌𝐶\sigma\colon Y\longrightarrow C of degree 111 such that Y𝑌Y is G𝐺G-birational to X𝑋X over C𝐶C and Y𝑌Y has at worst canonical Gorenstein singularities. Moreover, the generic fiber Yηsubscript𝑌𝜂Y_{\eta} of σ𝜎\sigma is non-singular, Yη≃Xηsimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑌𝜂subscript𝑋𝜂Y_{\eta}\simeq X_{\eta}, and the special fibers are reduced and irreducible.

Proof.

By Theorem 3.2 we may assume that the pair (X,ℋ)𝑋ℋ(X,\mathscr{H}) is canonical where ℋ=|−KX+π∗​D|ℋsubscript𝐾𝑋superscript𝜋𝐷\mathscr{H}=|-K_{X}+\pi^{*}D| for some G𝐺G-invariant ample Cartier divisor D𝐷D on C𝐶C. Let (X¯,ℋ¯)¯𝑋¯ℋ(\bar{X},\bar{\mathscr{H}}) be its G𝐺G-equivariant terminal modification over C𝐶C (see Proposition 4.2). By Lemma 1.9 the linear system ℋ¯¯ℋ\bar{\mathscr{H}} has at worst isolated non-singular base-points Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} such that multPi​ℋ¯=1subscriptmultsubscript𝑃𝑖¯ℋ1\mathrm{mult}_{P_{i}}\bar{\mathscr{H}}=1. Since X¯¯𝑋\bar{X} is terminal it has at worst isolated singular points. It follows that a general element of ℋ¯¯ℋ\bar{\mathscr{H}} is a Cartier divisor.

The linear system ℋ¯¯ℋ\bar{\mathscr{H}} is nef since it has no curves in its base locus. Restricting ℋ¯¯ℋ\bar{\mathscr{H}} to a general fiber of the morphism π¯:X¯⟶C:¯𝜋⟶¯𝑋𝐶{\bar{\pi}\colon\bar{X}\longrightarrow C} we notice that for any m≥2𝑚2m\geq 2 the image of the map given by the linear system |m​ℋ¯|𝑚¯ℋ|m\bar{\mathscr{H}}| is three-dimensional. Hence the linear system ℋ¯¯ℋ\bar{\mathscr{H}} is big. By Proposition 4.1 for some ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-Cartier divisors A𝐴A and N𝑁N we have

ℋ¯∼ℚA+N,ℚsimilar-to¯ℋ𝐴𝑁\bar{\mathscr{H}}\mathrel{\underset{\scriptscriptstyle{\mathbb{Q}}}{\sim}}A+N,

where A𝐴A is ample, N𝑁N is effective and the pair (X¯,N)¯𝑋𝑁(\bar{X},N) is terminal. By the construction of X¯¯𝑋\bar{X} we have KX¯+ℋ¯∼𝐶0𝐶similar-tosubscript𝐾¯𝑋¯ℋ0K_{\bar{X}}+\bar{\mathscr{H}}\mathrel{\underset{\scriptscriptstyle{C}}{\sim}}0, hence

KX¯+N∼ℚ,C−A.ℚ𝐶similar-tosubscript𝐾¯𝑋𝑁𝐴K_{\bar{X}}+N\mathrel{\underset{\scriptscriptstyle{\mathbb{Q},C}}{\sim}}-A.

Thus, for any curve Z∈NE¯​(X/C)𝑍¯NE𝑋𝐶Z\in\overline{\operatorname{NE}}(X/C) with Z⋅ℋ¯=0⋅𝑍¯ℋ0Z\cdot\bar{\mathscr{H}}=0 we have Z⋅(KX¯+N)<0⋅𝑍subscript𝐾¯𝑋𝑁0Z\cdot(K_{\bar{X}}+N)<0. By Contraction Theorem [KMM87, Theorem 3.2.1] the linear system |n​ℋ¯|𝑛¯ℋ|n\bar{\mathscr{H}}| gives a (G𝐺G-equivariant) contraction morphism g:X¯⟶Y:𝑔⟶¯𝑋𝑌g\colon\bar{X}\longrightarrow Y with connected fibers such that the variety Y𝑌Y is projective over C𝐶C and the following diagram is commutative

It also guarantees the existence of a σ𝜎\sigma-ample Cartier divisor H𝐻H on Y𝑌Y such that g∗​H=ℋ¯superscript𝑔𝐻¯ℋg^{*}{H}=\bar{\mathscr{H}}. Since ℋ¯¯ℋ\bar{\mathscr{H}} is ample on an open subset of X¯¯𝑋\bar{X} we see that g​(X¯)=Y𝑔¯𝑋𝑌g(\bar{X})=Y is three-dimensional. Hence g𝑔g is birational.

Now we prove that Y𝑌Y has Gorenstein canonical singularities. Since by construction of X¯¯𝑋\bar{X} we have KX¯+ℋ¯=π¯∗​Dsubscript𝐾¯𝑋¯ℋsuperscript¯𝜋𝐷K_{\bar{X}}+\bar{\mathscr{H}}=\bar{\pi}^{*}D for some ample divisor D𝐷D on C𝐶C and g∗​(KX¯+ℋ¯)=KY+Hsubscript𝑔subscript𝐾¯𝑋¯ℋsubscript𝐾𝑌𝐻g_{*}(K_{\bar{X}}+\bar{\mathscr{H}})=K_{Y}+H then from the commutativity of the diagram

KY+H=g∗​π¯∗​D=σ∗​D.subscript𝐾𝑌𝐻subscript𝑔superscript¯𝜋𝐷superscript𝜎𝐷K_{Y}+H=g_{*}\bar{\pi}^{*}D=\sigma^{*}D.

Thus KYsubscript𝐾𝑌K_{Y} is a Cartier divisor. We have

g∗​KY=g∗​(−H+σ∗​D)=−ℋ¯+π¯∗​D=KX¯.superscript𝑔subscript𝐾𝑌superscript𝑔𝐻superscript𝜎𝐷¯ℋsuperscript¯𝜋𝐷subscript𝐾¯𝑋g^{*}K_{Y}=g^{*}(-H+\sigma^{*}D)=-\bar{\mathscr{H}}+\bar{\pi}^{*}D=K_{\bar{X}}.

Hence Y𝑌Y has canonical singularities.

The fact that Yηsubscript𝑌𝜂Y_{\eta} is non-singular and Yη≃Xηsimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑌𝜂subscript𝑋𝜂Y_{\eta}\simeq X_{\eta} follows from Proposition 2.2. The special fibers are reduced and irreducible due to Lemma 1.8. It remains to show that Y𝑌Y is G​ℚ𝐺ℚG\mathbb{Q}-factorial. We show this in the next lemma.

Lemma 4.4.

Let σ:Y⟶C:𝜎⟶𝑌𝐶\sigma\colon Y\longrightarrow C be a generalised Gorenstein del Pezzo fibration of arbitrary degree with at worst canonical singularities. Suppose that the fibers of σ𝜎\sigma are reduced and irreducible. Then Y𝑌Y is ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-factorial.

Proof.

Since Y𝑌Y is canonical it has finitely many non-ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-factorial points by [Re85, 3.4]. Let F=∑Fi𝐹subscript𝐹𝑖F=\sum F_{i} be the union of the fibers of σ𝜎\sigma that contain all the points that are not ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-factorial. Write the excision exact sequence

⨁iℤ​Fi⟶Cl​Y⟶Cl​U⟶0⟶subscriptdirect-sum𝑖ℤsubscript𝐹𝑖Cl𝑌⟶Cl𝑈⟶0\bigoplus_{i}\mathbb{Z}F_{i}\longrightarrow\mathrm{Cl}\ Y\longrightarrow\mathrm{Cl}\ U\longrightarrow 0

where U=Y∖F𝑈𝑌𝐹U=Y\setminus F. Since U𝑈U is ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}-factorial we have Cl​U⊗ℚ=Pic​U⊗ℚtensor-productCl𝑈ℚtensor-productPic𝑈ℚ\mathrm{Cl}\ U\otimes\mathbb{Q}=\mathrm{Pic}\ U\otimes\mathbb{Q}. We see that any Weil divisor on Y𝑌Y after subtracting some number of fibers Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} and taking multiple comes from Pic​UPic𝑈\mathrm{Pic}\ U. So it is enough to prove that any Cartier divisor on U𝑈U extends to a Cartier divisor on Y𝑌Y. But this follows from the commutative diagram with exact rows (see [EGA, 21.4.3])

where V=σ​(U)𝑉𝜎𝑈V=\sigma(U). Indeed, the left vertical arrow is clearly surjective, hence by the Snake Lemma the middle vertical arrow is surjective as well. ∎

The theorem is proven. ∎

In the proof of the theorem by construction we have

Follows immediately from Propositions 1.7, 3.1, and Theorems 3.2, 4.3. ∎

5. Anticanonical algebra of a degree 111 del Pezzo surface

We need the following results on the anticanonical algebra

R=⨁m≥0H0​(S,−m​KS)𝑅subscriptdirect-sum𝑚0superscriptH0𝑆𝑚subscript𝐾𝑆R=\bigoplus_{m\geq 0}\mathrm{H}^{0}(S,-mK_{S})

of a degree 111 del Pezzo surface S𝑆S.

Proposition 5.1.

The following holds:

  1. (i)

    dimH0​(S,−m​KS)=m​(m+1)/2+1;dimensionsuperscriptH0𝑆𝑚subscript𝐾𝑆𝑚𝑚121\dim\mathrm{H}^{0}(S,-mK_{S})=m(m+1)/2+1;

  2. (ii)

    the linear system |−KS|subscript𝐾𝑆|-K_{S}| has one simple base-point;

  3. (iii)

    the linear system |−2​KS|2subscript𝐾𝑆|-2K_{S}| is generated by global sections;

  4. (iv)

    the linear system |−3​KS|3subscript𝐾𝑆|-3K_{S}| is very ample.

Proof.

Let S𝑆S be normal. In this case, the statements (i)–(iv) are well known if S𝑆S is non-singular. In the singular case see [HW81, §4].

Let S𝑆S be non-normal and let α:T⟶S:𝛼⟶𝑇𝑆\alpha\colon T\longrightarrow S be its normalisation. According to [R94, 1.1] (see also [AF03, 1.5]) we have

T≃ℙ2,α∗​(−KS)≃𝒪ℙ2​(1).formulae-sequencesimilar-to-or-equals𝑇superscriptℙ2similar-to-or-equalssuperscript𝛼subscript𝐾𝑆subscript𝒪superscriptℙ21T\simeq\mathbb{P}^{2},\quad\alpha^{*}(-K_{S})\simeq\mathscr{O}_{\mathbb{P}^{2}}(1).

It is proven there that α𝛼\alpha is an isomorphism outside a (possibly singular) conic Q𝑄Q on ℙ2superscriptℙ2\mathbb{P}^{2}, and the morphism α|Qevaluated-at𝛼𝑄\alpha|_{Q} is a 222 to 111 covering over a curve on S𝑆S.

According to [AF03, 2.2] for any m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1 the following holds:

dimH0​(T,α∗​(−m​KS))=dimH0​(S,−m​KS)+m.dimensionsuperscriptH0𝑇superscript𝛼𝑚subscript𝐾𝑆dimensionsuperscriptH0𝑆𝑚subscript𝐾𝑆𝑚\dim\mathrm{H}^{0}(T,\alpha^{*}(-mK_{S}))=\dim\mathrm{H}^{0}(S,-mK_{S})+m.

Hence we get

dimH0​(S,−m​KS)=dimH0​(ℙ2,𝒪ℙ2​(m))−m=(m+1)​(m+2)/2−m=m​(m+1)/2+1.dimensionsuperscriptH0𝑆𝑚subscript𝐾𝑆dimensionsuperscriptH0superscriptℙ2subscript𝒪superscriptℙ2𝑚𝑚𝑚1𝑚22𝑚𝑚𝑚121\dim\mathrm{H}^{0}(S,-mK_{S})=\dim\mathrm{H}^{0}(\mathbb{P}^{2},\mathscr{O}_{\mathbb{P}^{2}}(m))-m=(m+1)(m+2)/2-m=m(m+1)/2+1.

This proves (i). The statements (ii) и (iv) are proven in [AF03, 1.2, 1.5(A)], see also [R94, 4.10 (ii)].

Since we have |σ∗​(−KS)|=|𝒪ℙ2​(1)|superscript𝜎subscript𝐾𝑆subscript𝒪superscriptℙ21|\sigma^{*}(-K_{S})|=|\mathscr{O}_{\mathbb{P}^{2}}(1)|, all the elements of the linear system |−KS|subscript𝐾𝑆|-K_{S}| are irreducible. By the adjunction formula they are curves of arithmetic genus 111. Since they are rational these curves are either nodal or cuspidal cubic curves. For any C∈|−3​KS|𝐶3subscript𝐾𝑆C\in|-3K_{S}| we have the following exact sequence

0⟶𝒪S​(−3​KS−C)⟶𝒪S​(−3​KS)⟶𝒪C​(−3​KS)⟶0.⟶0subscript𝒪𝑆3subscript𝐾𝑆𝐶⟶subscript𝒪𝑆3subscript𝐾𝑆⟶subscript𝒪𝐶3subscript𝐾𝑆⟶00\longrightarrow\mathscr{O}_{S}(-3K_{S}-C)\longrightarrow\mathscr{O}_{S}(-3K_{S})\longrightarrow\mathscr{O}_{C}(-3K_{S})\longrightarrow 0.

Since any linear system on the curve C𝐶C of degree 222 or more does not have base-points and H1​(S,𝒪S)=0superscriptH1𝑆subscript𝒪𝑆0\mathrm{H}^{1}(S,\mathscr{O}_{S})=0, the statement (iii) follows. ∎

Corollary 5.2.
  1. (i)

    The linear system |−2​KS|2subscript𝐾𝑆|-2K_{S}| defines a two-fold covering of the quadratic cone

    ϕ=ϕ|−2​KS|:S⟶Q⊂ℙ3.:italic-ϕsubscriptitalic-ϕ2subscript𝐾𝑆⟶𝑆𝑄superscriptℙ3\phi=\phi_{|-2K_{S}|}\colon S\longrightarrow Q\subset\mathbb{P}^{3}.
  2. (ii)

    The algebra R=⨁m≥0H0​(S,−m​KS)𝑅subscriptdirect-sum𝑚0superscriptH0𝑆𝑚subscript𝐾𝑆R=\bigoplus_{m\geq 0}\mathrm{H}^{0}(S,-mK_{S}) is isomorphic to ℂ​[x,y,z,w]/(f)ℂ𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑤𝑓\mathbb{C}[x,y,z,w]/(f) where the degree of generators are 1,1,2,311231,1,2,3 correspondingly and the relation f𝑓f has degree 666. Hence, S𝑆S is isomorphic to the degree 666 hypersurface in the weighted projective space ℙ​(1,1,2,3)ℙ1123\mathbb{P}(1,1,2,3).

Proof.

Follows from the previous proposition in full analogy to the non-singular case, see [Do12, 8.3]. ∎

Proof of Theorem B.
